events.summary: Paul Dukas entered the world in Paris, where the future composer was born into a Jewish family. One can only wonder how his parents celebrated this moment, possibly with a symphonic lullaby.

At 16, Dukas finally found his musical calling at the Conservatoire de Paris after years of being about as musically inclined as a brick. He studied piano, harmony, and composition before bonding with a fellow student, Claude Debussy, whose talent was unmistakably bigger than his.
It took a bout of illness to turn Dukas from a mere piano student into a composer when he started composing at 14. One could say, 'Health is wealth', especially if it leads to musical genius!

Dukas channeled his inner overachiever and scored second place at the prestigious Prix de Rome for his cantata Velléda. Leaving the Conservatoire in a huff after missing the top spot, he clearly took 'second best' to a whole new level.

His Parisian debut came with a performance of Polyeucte. The critics must have thought they were in for a magical night, and they weren't wrong, although with Dukas probably being overly critical, one wonders if he was satisfied!

Dukas composed his most famous work, L'apprenti sorcier, which inadvertently turned into his musical identity crisis as its popularity overshadowed all his other compositions. Who knew that a sorcerer's apprentice could steal the whole show?

Dukas decided to take the plunge and marry Suzanne Pereyra, a choice that suggested he was ready to share his life with someone as wonderful (and possibly as musical) as he was. They welcomed a daughter (probably expecting to raise a future musician).

Dukas premiered his lush ballet La Péri, a work that featured a prince on a quest that surely beat attending family dinners in excitement. The composer's flair matched the exoticness of the story, leaving audiences wondering if they were experiencing music or magic.

In 1927, Dukas stepped into the nurturing role of professor of composition at the Paris Conservatoire, leaving behind a legacy beyond his own compositions. He encouraged students to express themselves, proving he was more than a critic of his own work; he was a mentor!

events.event: Membership of the Académie des Beaux-Arts
events.summary: Dukas received the prestigious honor of being elected to the Académie des Beaux-Arts, a fitting tribute to a man who spent his life bridging the gap between art and music. One can only imagine the pomp and circumstance at this esteemed gathering, which he likely approached with his usual modesty.

He was inducted into the prestigious Royal Academy of Science, Letters and Fine Arts of Belgium, which was like getting a VIP pass to the coolest club in the arts, complete with snacks and an open bar of creativity.

He composed 'The Sorcerer's Apprentice,' which turned out to be so popular that it basically made him the household name of orchestral music—imagine if your mom replaced all cooking shows with this musical piece!

His opera 'Ariane et Barbe-bleue' was in the spotlight for nearly a decade before finally making its grand debut—proving that sometimes, the path to success is a bit like waiting for a bus that keeps getting delayed.
He debuted 'La Péri,' which was so spectacular that it redefined ballet and ensured ballet dancers would never run out of reasons to wear fabulous tutus.

compositions.title: La plainte, au loin, du faune
Variations, interlude et final sur un thème de Rameau
